posts.title: Public Square • Thankful For
posts.subtitle: This month we want to see what you're thankful for.
posts.teaser: Every month we team up with NPR to bring you Public Square -- a community Instagram project. For November, we want to see what you're thankful for.
posts.body:
It's time again for our Public Square community project with NPR.

November's Theme: #PSThankfulFor 

Since Thanksgiving is almost upon us, we want to see the people, places and things that you're thankful for.

It could be someone close to you, the view from your window or the smile from a stranger. Get creative, capture your subject in a photo or video and tag it #PSThankfulFor.

In the caption please tell us who/what you are thankful for and why.

Public radio is all about storytelling, so please don't skimp on the caption! While we love pretty pictures, we are suckers for a good story.

Project Rules

Please tag only one photo posted to Instagram from November 15th to 30th with #PSThankfulFor.

Any image posted with the tag in the next 15 days is eligible to featured here on Instagram, KPCC's AudioVision and NPR's The Picture Show.

You can follow KPCC and NPR on Instagram for project updates.

Have fun telling your story! We can't wait to see it.

category.title: Images
category.description: The heartbeat of AudioVision. The best from our team of photojournalists — and discover images from the photographers who inspire them.

assets.title: #PSThankfulFor Public Square
assets.caption: For our Public Square Instagram project in November we want to see your photos of the people, places and things that you're thankful for. Tag your images #PSThankfulFor.

posts.title: Exploring industrial Los Angeles
posts.subtitle: Stella Kalinina looks at the machines that make L.A.
posts.teaser: Los Angeles is a land of machines, from the cars that crowd our freeways to the ships that come in to our ports. Visual artist Stella Kalinina films them.
posts.body:
Los Angeles is a land of machines, from the cars that crowd our freeways to the cranes that unload ships in our parts.

Visual artist Stella Kalinina is in the middle of a project that explores parts of the machinery of America's second largest city.

Her first video takes you to the Port of Los Angeles where huge machines offload the goods that fuel American commerce.

Kalinina, a student at Art Center College in Pasadena, blends sound and visuals in an interesting way that gives the machinations of the port a new life.

Her second video explores the pumpjacks that dot the hills of Long Beach and along La Cienega Boulevard.

The images are interspersed with audio of residents talking about their neighbors that suck oil from the earth like birds drinking from a straw.

(Via LA, I'm Yours)

category.title: Video
category.description: Southern California, as seen through our own eyes — and a tour of the best in web video today.

posts.title: Inside the world of illustrator Michael Hsiung
posts.subtitle: Learn what makes this LA-based artist tick.
posts.teaser: LA-based artist Michael Hsiung was never comfortable in a suit in tie. Learn how he left the corporate world behind and pursued his passion as an illustrator.
posts.body:
Michael Hsiung is a product of Southern California; he was born in Chinatown, raised in the Valley and consumed by skateboard and surfing culture.

After stints in the corporate world, Hsiung realized he was much happier as an illustrator and decided to take off from his nine to five job.

Learn more about Hsiung's philosophy and career in this video by Ambig and Hidden Notice.

category.title: Video
category.description: Southern California, as seen through our own eyes — and a tour of the best in web video today.

assets.title: Michael Hammer Hsiung
